added_lines: from dragonflow.db import models if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(security_group_id): return if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(security_group_id): return if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(security_group_id): return if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(security_group_id): return secgroup_id, if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(secgroup_id): conj_id, priority = self._get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority( secgroup_id) def _install_security_group_rule_flows(self, secgroup_id, secgroup_rule): conj_id, priority = self._get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority( secgroup_id) def _get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority(self, secgroup_id): sg_unique_key = self.db_store.get_unique_key_by_id( models.SecurityGroup.table_name, secgroup_id) return sg_unique_key, (SG_PRIORITY_OFFSET + sg_unique_key) def _is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(self, secgroup_id): return self.secgroup_associate_local_ports.get(secgroup_id) is None def add_security_group_rule(self, secgroup, secgroup_rule): secgroup_id = secgroup.get_id() if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(secgroup_id): LOG.debug("Security group %s wasn't associated with a local port", secgroup_id) LOG.info(_LI("Add a rule %(rule)s to security group %(secgroup)s"), {'rule': secgroup_rule, 'secgroup': secgroup_id}) self._install_security_group_rule_flows(secgroup_id, secgroup_rule) secgroup_id = secgroup.get_id() if self._is_sg_not_associated_with_local_port(secgroup_id): LOG.debug("Security group %s wasn't associated with a local port", secgroup_id) return LOG.info(_LI("Remove a rule %(rule)s to security group %(secgroup)s"), {'rule': secgroup_rule, 'secgroup': secgroup.get_id()})
deleted_lines: self.secgroup_mappings = {} # When the value of a conj_id match is zero, it can match every # packets with no conj_id, which is not we expected. So We simply skip # the value of zero, and allocate conj_ids begin with one. self.next_secgroup_id = 1 if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group %s is none"), security_group_id) return if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group %s is none"), security_group_id) return if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group (%s) is none"), security_group_id) return if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group %s is none"), security_group_id) return secgroup, conj_id, priority = self._get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority(secgroup) if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group (%s) is none"), secgroup) def _install_security_group_rule_flows(self, secgroup, secgroup_rule): conj_id, priority = self._get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority(secgroup) if conj_id is None: LOG.error(_LE("the conj_id of the security group %s is none"), secgroup) return def _allocate_security_group_id(self, lgroup_id): # allocate a number security_id = self.next_secgroup_id LOG.info(_LI("allocate a number %(security_id)s to the security group " "%(lgroup_id)s") % {'security_id': security_id, 'lgroup_id': lgroup_id}) self.next_secgroup_id += 1 # save in DB # TODO(yuanwei) # save in local mapping self.secgroup_mappings[lgroup_id] = security_id def _release_security_group_id(self, lgroup_id): # release in local mapping security_id = self.secgroup_mappings.get(lgroup_id) LOG.info(_LI("release the allocated number %(security_id)s of the" "security group %(lgroup_id)s") % {'security_id': security_id, 'lgroup_id': lgroup_id}) if security_id is not None: del self.secgroup_mappings[lgroup_id] # release in DB # TODO(yuan wei) # release this number # TODO(yuan wei) def _get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority(self, lgroup_id): security_id = self.secgroup_mappings.get(lgroup_id) if security_id is not None: return security_id, (SG_PRIORITY_OFFSET + security_id) return None, None self._allocate_security_group_id(secgroup_id) self._release_security_group_id(secgroup_id) def add_security_group_rule(self, secgroup, secgroup_rule): LOG.info(_LI("add a rule %(rule)s to security group %(secgroup)s") % {'rule': secgroup_rule, 'secgroup': secgroup.get_id()}) conj_id, priority = \ self._get_secgroup_conj_id_and_priority(secgroup.get_id()) if conj_id is None: # this security group wasn't associated with a local port LOG.info(_LI("this security group %s wasn't associated with" " a local port"), secgroup.get_id()) self._install_security_group_rule_flows( secgroup.get_id(), secgroup_rule) LOG.info(_LI("remove a rule %(rule)s to security group %(secgroup)s") % {'rule': secgroup_rule, 'secgroup': secgroup.get_id()}) if conj_id is None: # this security group wasn't associated with a local port LOG.info(_LI("this security group %s wasn't associated with" " a local port"), secgroup.get_id()) return

commit_message:
Apply virtual tunnel port to l2 app

The virtual tunnel port will not have remote ip. This patch
adds remote ip to the packet in l2 app. So that one virtual
tunnel port can be shared by multiple remote chassis.

Change-Id: I847f65bd4bae27db99a942c54d251458a8d9ba20
Partially-implements: blueprint virtual-tunnel-port-support

commit_message:
add access_key to share_access_map

Receive it as return value of driver allow_access()
Store in ShareAccessMapping model
Expose it in access_get_all API

Implements: blueprint auth-access-keys
Change-Id: Ice814a9b7f918431c8cc1c6c840a0f877a9a74ea

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-09 07:10:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow/commit/8c94bed4278f9cbefb474c150eaa322e6ba5541d', 'message': "add implementation of allowed address pairs using active detection mechanism

This patch is the implementation of allowed address pairs blueprint, and
it only support using active detection method for now.
The main change are:
1) Add a struct named 'activenode' in DF DB, and it used to save the detected
active VM port of a allowed address pairs.
2) Add a app named allowed_address_pairs_app. This app used to detect the
active VM port by sending ARP requests and receiving the replies or the
gratuitous ARPs.
3) Modify apps like l2_app and l3_app to install flows to forward packets
to the detected actively VM port when a active node is detected.
4) Add fullstack cases about this feature.

Change-Id: Iaba7e719770556468bf36df56d330100361d5f84

commit_message:
add active detection app for allowed address pairs

This patch implement the active detection app for allowed
address pairs.
The main changes are:
1) Add a struct named 'activeport' in DF DB, and it is used to save
the detected active VM port of a allowed address pairs.
2) Add a app named active_port_detection_app. This app is used to
detect the active VM port by sending ARP requests and receiving the
replies or the gratuitous ARPs.
3) Add fullstack cases about this feature.

Partially-Implements: blueprint allowed-address-pairs
Change-Id: Iaba7e719770556468bf36df56d330100361d5f84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/75/339975/51 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def notify_update_active_node(self, active_node, old_active_node): self.dispatcher.dispatch('update_active_node', active_node=active_node, old_active_node=old_active_node) def notify_remove_active_node(self, active_node): self.dispatcher.dispatch('remove_active_node', active_node)

subject: Add Constraints support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-21 00:16:46.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/i18n/commit/2f6730fc11a56430748ef3fdc33a681c815b6b0b', 'message': "Add Constraints support

To be co-installable with other OpenStack projects and have consistent
testing it's a good idea (tm) to use constraints when creating tox
environments.

Change-Id: I776ac1ae0ef5067bc9679cad97a643ec8f852eb9
"}]
commit_message:
Add Constraints support

To be co-installable with other OpenStack projects and have consistent
testing it's a good idea (tm) to use constraints when creating tox
environments.

Change-Id: I776ac1ae0ef5067bc9679cad97a643ec8f852eb9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/i18n refs/changes/82/413282/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = pip install -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Remove duplicate setup code from test_tempurl.py

TestTempURLPrefix.setUp() almost duplicates the superclass
setUp method, except it set "expires" as an instance variable.
The duplicated setUp code can be removed by simply having the
super class setUp set the "expires" instance variable.

Change-Id: Icf7604460e475523e156daa8c578765336820c8e

subject: Add __ne__ built-in function
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-16 08:23:27.000000000', 'files': ['tackerclient/tests/unit/test_cli10.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tackerclient/commit/2b3b1792d5b72e6c0e499f9ecc2c4d2cf7ba65d6', 'message': 'Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you define
__eq__ for it to work properly [1]. There are no implied relationships
among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y does not imply that
x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining __eq__(), one should also
define __ne__() so that the operators will behave as expected.

[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

Change-Id: I6adceadb6e3749e34cf847654f28a3b6eea832fd
'}]
commit_message:
Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you define
__eq__ for it to work properly [1]. There are no implied relationships
among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y does not imply that
x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining __eq__(), one should also
define __ne__() so that the operators will behave as expected.

[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

Change-Id: I6adceadb6e3749e34cf847654f28a3b6eea832fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tackerclient refs/changes/78/398178/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __ne__(self, rhs): return not self.__eq__(rhs)

commit_message:
Bump revision of resource on tag add/remove

This updates the tag to bump the revision of the standard
attr record it's associated with. This required a small change
to include a bump revision method directly on the standard
attr records.

Closes-Bug: #1643879
Change-Id: Ia096cd342ed3eeec33a8ae64efe13d469c375dd6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/67/408867/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class AutoBumpRevision(object): """Informs revision plugin to bump revision on commits.""" def bump_revision(self): # SQLAlchemy will bump the version for us automatically if the # standard attr record is being modified, but we must call this # for all other modifications or when relevant children are being # modified (e.g. fixed_ips change should bump port revision) if self.standard_attr.revision_number is None: # this is a brand new object uncommitted so we don't bump now return self.standard_attr.revision_number += 1 class HasStandardAttributes(AutoBumpRevision):
deleted_lines: class HasStandardAttributes(object): def bump_revision(self): # SQLAlchemy will bump the version for us automatically if the # standard attr record is being modified, but we must call this # for all other modifications or when relevant children are being # modified (e.g. fixed_ips change should bump port revision) if self.standard_attr.revision_number is None: # this is a brand new object uncommitted so we don't bump now return self.standard_attr.revision_number += 1

Add Constraints support

testing it's a good idea (tm) to use constraints when creating tox
environments.

commit_message:
Fix 'No data to report' error in coverage.

Remove unnecessary commands in 'testenv:cover' of tox.ini.
HTML coverage reports can be generated in 'cover' directory by
'python setup.py testr --coverage' only.

Change-Id: I6bc205c4a7772a11cd3dc911a52097e62444376f
Closes-Bug: #1651029

commit_message:
Avoid Forcing the Translation of Translatable Variables

Translation can also be delayed for variables that potentially contain
translatable objects such as exceptions.
Whenever possible translation should not be forced by use of six.text_type()
on a message being used with a format string.
This patch allows the translation of the translatable replacement text to be
delayed until the message is translated.
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#avoid-forcing-the-translation-of-translatable-variables

Change-Id: I5e259368cbf135116bb3b631835227caa1825894

commit_message:
replace assertTrue with assertLess.

[H203] Use 'assertLess(first, second, msg=None)' to check for 
value Unit test assertions tend to give better messages 
for more specific assertions.

Change-Id: I902400d13c6e3e81333e76597430adb4015b4623

commit_message:
Fixed the __ne__ implementation in base.Resource

Any object of Resource class or its child class do not compare with
None as expected. For example if a server has been found and is
clearly not None, the test "server!=None" will be False.

This was occuring because the __eq__ implementation was returning the
'NotImplemented' keyword and the __ne__ implementation was returning
the not of __eq__, which in this case will return False as the
expected python behavior for a the not of NotImplemented is False.

Changed the __ne__ implementation to return the correct boolean value
and added the test case that fails with the older implementation and
passes in the current fix.

Change-Id: I6bf5a6e9c9eed4bbcf6678467df19dfea560b4de
Closes-Bug: #1648207

deleted_lines: return not self.__eq__(other)

commit_message:
Align the stars to unblock instack-undercloud gate on stable/newton

We need to squash to patches if we want to unblock stable/newton CI.

First patch:

Fix bashate errors and warnings (lint)

Fix 1 warning and 1 error in bash syntax:

1) E043: Arithmetic compound has inconsistent return semantics.
   Fix the bash syntax to be compliant.

2) ERROR: Split export and assignments in 2 files. Ignore the files.
   Fix the bash syntax to be compliant.
   Note: this test has been introducted by
   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/400542/

(cherry picked from commit 9031dcf62016c5ca198a39109425b9f063e131fc)

Second Patch:

Run `yum update -y` before Puppet run

This patch run `yum update -y` right before running os-refresh-config
(Puppet).

1) Running `yum` from an Exec in Puppet is a bad idea because Puppet has
no idea which packages resources are touched, so we're loosing the
orchestration control.

2) We need to ensure that `yum update -y` runs before any attempt to
deploy OpenStack services, so we have latest packages from RDO and
CentOS.

Closes-Bug: #1650374
(cherry picked from commit 853b4bfbadda67cf659a8a744b82d128a4bc3247)

Change-Id: Ifbbbdbf1f0c569791abc712913c7e0f6bbe533d9

commit_message:
Fix Kolla-Kubernetes developer quickstart guide

Kolla-Kubernetes developer quickstart guide minor clean-up:

- Section: "Running Kolla-Kubernetes"
Reworded to make it simpler

- Section: "Generate Credentials"
Rewording of the first sentance, remove unwanted "an"

- Section: "Web Access"
Reworded "horizon website" -> "horizon dashboard"

- Other minor fixes

Closes-Bug: #1650726

Change-Id: I98367ea790aaeba762248a2d133e0dbba8f62669
Signed-off-by: Ashish Billore <ashish.billore@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add tracing flag to dib invocations

Add the "-x" tracing flag to dib invocations so we get a full trace in
the logs.  This is very helpful for debugging issues from logs.

Change-Id: I8ff17709e16cd32c183d69b6880776a9c68647d2

commit_message:
Change common dependency container to convert env var names to uppercase

This ps changes the values propagated from values.yaml to uppercase for the
entrypoint init container. Which means that we do not mix case, leading to a
more consistent set of configuration parameter keys.

Change-Id: I4bdad59cbccd286f5d8d31380d9bd16965e22a22

commit_message:
Replaces uuid.uuid4 with uuidutils.generate_uuid()

Openstack common has a wrapper for generating uuids. We should
use that function when generating uuids for consistency.

Change-Id: Ic6045a3b8dabedf3ecaa14d94707614fc4d454e4
Closes-Bug: #1082248

commit_message:
Expire segments when expiring large objects

...but only segments that were uploaded via swiftclient.

In general, there is a many-to-many relationship between large objects
and segments. That is, a single segment may be used by multiple large
objects, or even used directly. As a result, when POSTing a new
expiration date to a large object, we should not in general also POST to
the segments.

However, when the large object was created through swiftclient, each
segment should only be used by a single large object. As a result,

* During large object creation, we can include the same X-Delete-At /
  X-Delete-After headers on the segments that we used for the manifest.

* Following a POST that includes X-(Remove-)Delete-(At|After) headers,
  we can check whether the target was a manifest and if so, apply the
  same headers to segments which seem to have been created by
  swiftclient.

Related-Bug: 1514606
Related-Bug: 1159951
Closes-Bug: 1478830
Change-Id: I2f7aed81906c2093a3c2aa9b9bcdb6eb2eb4554a

commit_message:
Update tox configuration file to reduce duplication

While reviewing a separate patch in which an entire test environment was
simply copied and pasted just to change the basepython attribute, I
realized Glance could utilize tox's feature set in a much more efficient
manner.

Tox allows you to generate envlists, have "factor-conditional" settings,
and other "factor-conditional" conditions since version 1.8:
https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#generative-envlist
A good minimum version, though, is 2.3.1 because it has made support for
these features more robust and a lot of bugs have since been fixed.

Change-Id: Ia44a37177d57b972c4c9d0f179291b0c8316dd95

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-19 16:22:57.000000000', 'files': ['templates/ironic.conf.j2', 'tasks/ironic_post_install.yml', 'defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_ironic/commit/96b98eddb2ab41a26a2497c4ed01a0188ffbb03d', 'message': 'Fix ironic_api_url value

The api_url value is wrong and causes gate failures now that the value
is tested by the ironic server when it starts up.

Change-Id: I7d63135a74b6472a284495f04d7c04dc553f53ad
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ironic_api_url value

The api_url value is wrong and causes gate failures now that the value
is tested by the ironic server when it starts up.

Change-Id: I7d63135a74b6472a284495f04d7c04dc553f53ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_ironic refs/changes/18/412518/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #ironic_openstack_api_url: '' # Not required when we have keystoneironic_standalone_api_url: "{{ ironic_service_internaluri }}/"
deleted_lines: ironic_openstack_api_url: '' # Not required when we have keystoneironic_standalone_api_url: "api_url={{ ironic_service_internaluri }}/"

commit_message:
Add releasenote CI for Zaqar client.

We'll support reno and release doc for zaqar client in this cycle.

Add the CI to make sure the releasenote works well.

Change-Id: Ib23974ee971b4b646ff8b225b1cccf6cd40d6401

added_lines: - name: release-notes-jobs

subject: RBD: Implement v2.1 replication
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-23 20:20:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/58d20da3417663ecc20b9ee1baaf1d0e6e226f3c', 'message': 'WIP: RBD: add support for volume replication

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-29 19:54:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1ef53bf3e2c8c4246b9e2401a9b21bacd61fdb45', 'message': 'WIP: RBD: add support for volume replication

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-08-04 19:27:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/adb1546862a4b925447f7e1025fa81a80bc7605c', 'message': "RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported and requires admin intervention to
reach a per-failover state.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder,
                         pool:volumes

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2016-09-08 19:57:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/5cb77e0c2903b5119b934654f48a6d43584a2550', 'message': "RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported by Cinder and requires admin
intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2016-09-09 19:26:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/5b4684b49e9c255a2f85be40660e47141d991942', 'message': "RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported by Cinder and requires admin
intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

We also have a new configuration option for the RBD driver called
replication_connect_timeout that allows us to specify the timeout for
the promotion/demotion of a single volume.

We try to do a clean failover for cases where there is still
connectivity with the primary cluster, so we'll try to do a demotion of
the original images, and when one of the demotions fails we just assume
that all of the other demotions will fail as well (the cluster is not
accesible) so we'll do a forceful promotion for those images.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d
"}, {'number': 14, 'created': '2016-09-09 22:39:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/41129eedc0b505f137dbaec2dea8bb23b8febf33', 'message': "RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported by Cinder and requires admin
intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

We also have a new configuration option for the RBD driver called
replication_connect_timeout that allows us to specify the timeout for
the promotion/demotion of a single volume.

We try to do a clean failover for cases where there is still
connectivity with the primary cluster, so we'll try to do a demotion of
the original images, and when one of the demotions fails we just assume
that all of the other demotions will fail as well (the cluster is not
accesible) so we'll do a forceful promotion for those images.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d
"}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2016-09-22 20:01:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/da5581cded1e5ce784c8779fb14489e0e096c76e', 'message': "RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported by Cinder and requires admin
intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

The only required parameter is backend_id, as conf and user have
defaults.  Conf defaults to /etc/ceph/$backend_id.conf and user defaults
to rbd_user or cinder if that one is None.

We also have a new configuration option for the RBD driver called
replication_connect_timeout that allows us to specify the timeout for
the promotion/demotion of a single volume.

We try to do a clean failover for cases where there is still
connectivity with the primary cluster, so we'll try to do a demotion of
the original images, and when one of the demotions fails we just assume
that all of the other demotions will fail as well (the cluster is not
accesible) so we'll do a forceful promotion for those images.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d

intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

The only required parameter is backend_id, as conf and user have
defaults.  Conf defaults to /etc/ceph/$backend_id.conf and user defaults
to rbd_user or cinder if that one is None.

We also have a new configuration option for the RBD driver called
replication_connect_timeout that allows us to specify the timeout for
the promotion/demotion of a single volume.

We try to do a clean failover for cases where there is still
connectivity with the primary cluster, so we'll try to do a demotion of
the original images, and when one of the demotions fails we just assume
that all of the other demotions will fail as well (the cluster is not
accesible) so we'll do a forceful promotion for those images.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d

commit_message:
RBD: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements v2.1 replication in the RBD driver.  A single ceph
backend can support both replicated and non-replicated volumes using
volume types.  For replicated volumes, both clusters are expected to be
configured with rbd-mirror with keys in place and image mirroring
enabled on the pool.  The RBD driver will enable replication per-volume
if the volume type requests it.

On failover, each replicated volume is promoted to primary on the
secondary cluster and new connection requests will receive connection
information for the volume on the secondary cluster.  At the time of
writing, failback is not supported by Cinder and requires admin
intervention to reach a per-failover state.

Non replicated volumes will be set to error status to reflect that they
are not available, and the previous status will be stored in the
replication_driver_data field.

There are two configuration pieces required to make this work:

1. A volume type that enables replication:

    $ cinder type-create replicated
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set volume_backend_name=ceph
    $ cinder type-key    replicated set replication_enabled='<is> True'

2. A secondary backend defined in cinder.conf:

    [ceph]
    ...
    replication_device = backend_id:secondary,
                         conf:/etc/ceph/secondary.conf,
                         user:cinder

The only required parameter is backend_id, as conf and user have
defaults.  Conf defaults to /etc/ceph/$backend_id.conf and user defaults
to rbd_user or cinder if that one is None.

We also have a new configuration option for the RBD driver called
replication_connect_timeout that allows us to specify the timeout for
the promotion/demotion of a single volume.

We try to do a clean failover for cases where there is still
connectivity with the primary cluster, so we'll try to do a demotion of
the original images, and when one of the demotions fails we just assume
that all of the other demotions will fail as well (the cluster is not
accesible) so we'll do a forceful promotion for those images.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint rbd-replication
Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I58c38fe11014aaade6b42f4bdf9d32b73c82e18d

added_lines: from cinder import contextfrom cinder.volume import volume_types self.replication_enabled = False def do_setup(self, context): """Performs initialization steps that could raise exceptions.""" self._setup_replication() def _setup_replication(self): replication_devices = self.configuration.safe_get( 'replication_device') if replication_devices: self._parse_replication_devices(replication_devices) self.replication_enabled = True LOG.info(_LI('Replication is enabled.')) def _parse_replication_devices(self, devices): for device in devices: backend_id = device['backend_id'] LOG.info(_LI('Adding \"%(id)s\" to replication targets.'), {'id': backend_id}) stats['replication_enabled'] = self.replication_enabled try: self._enable_replication_if_needed(volume) except Exception: self.RBDProxy().remove(client.ioctx, volume.name) err_msg = (_('Failed to enable image replication')) raise exception.ReplicationError(reason=err_msg, volume_id=volume.id) def _enable_replication(self, volume): with RBDVolumeProxy(self, volume.name) as image: image.update_features(self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING, True) image.mirror_image_enable() def _is_volume_replicated_type(self, volume): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() volume_type = volume_types.get_volume_type(ctxt, volume["volume_type_id"]) replication_flag = False specs = volume_type.get("extra_specs") if specs and "replication_enabled" in specs: replication_capability = specs["replication_enabled"] replication_flag = (replication_capability == "<is> True") return replication_flag def _enable_replication_if_needed(self, volume): if self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume): self._enable_replication(volume) try: self._enable_replication_if_needed(volume) except Exception: self.RBDProxy().remove(client.ioctx, volume.name) err_msg = (_('Failed to enable image replication')) raise exception.ReplicationError(reason=err_msg, volume_id=volume.id) try: self._enable_replication_if_needed(volume) except Exception: self.RBDProxy().remove(client.ioctx, volume.name) err_msg = (_('Failed to enable image replication')) raise exception.ReplicationError(reason=err_msg, volume_id=volume.id) def _disable_replication(self, volume): """Disable replication on the given volume.""" with RBDVolumeProxy(self, volume.name) as image: image.mirror_image_disable(False) image.update_features(self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING, False) def retype(self, context, volume, new_type, diff, host): """Retype from one volume type to another on the same backend.""" previous_vol_replicated = self._is_volume_replicated_type(volume) new_vol_replicated = False if new_type: specs = new_type.get("extra_specs") if specs and "replication_enabled" in specs: replication_capability = specs["replication_enabled"] # Do not validate settings, ignore invalid. new_vol_replicated = (replication_capability == "<is> True") if previous_vol_replicated and not new_vol_replicated: self._disable_replication(volume) elif not previous_vol_replicated and new_vol_replicated: self._enable_replication(volume) return True, None
deleted_lines: def retype(self, context, volume, new_type, diff, host): """Retypes a volume, allow Qos and extra_specs change.""" # No need to check encryption, extra_specs and Qos here as: # encryptions have been checked as same. # extra_specs are not used in the driver. # Qos settings are not used in the driver. LOG.debug('RBD retype called for volume %s. No action ' 'required for RBD volumes.', volume.id) return True

commit_message:
Allow purging of records less than 1 day old.

Adding ability to purge records less than 1 day old, using the
glance-manage db_purge utility.

Closes-Bug: #1643287

Change-Id: Ibaea583d49bd5d09ad2e6bf99d2c0efaac5cb4ec

commit_message:
Remove enable_v1 and enable_v2 parameters for lbaas

1) enable_v1 and enable_v2 parameters are deprecated and will be
   removed in Ocata, so we can remove them.
2) Fix firewall_driver option value.
3) Fix the annotation of driver parameter.

commit_message:
Add image preallocation mode option

Image preallocation allows storage to be fully allocated at
instance start. This should significantly improve performance
on writes to new blocks and may even improve I/O performance
to prewritten blocks due to reduced fragmentation.

Change-Id: I1be99c9af8f32b1a7f8408ddeb695fd05a603ace

commit_message:
Removing ironic-webclient gating for retirement

Per the annoucement[0] to the openstack-dev mailing list,
this change removes the gating from ironic-webclient to
allow us to retire the ironic-webclient.

Additionally, the '{name}-nodejs{version}-npm-publish-draft'
template was only used by the ironic-webclient to publish a
working draft for users to review. As it is no longer used
anywhere else, it must be removed in order to permit tests
to pass.

[0]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-December/109195.html

Change-Id: Ie6d940a071f158be647dd86c32752e5988d7c968

commit_message:
use six.StringIO for compatibility with io.StringIO in python3

The newer version of six (1.4.1) provides six.StringIO
which is a fake file object for textual data. It's an
alias for cStringIO.StringIO, in python2 and io.StringIO
in Python3

Change-Id: I5f4af05eb0754d85a73068d5f6b285d4be07cdfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/23/412723/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six buff = six.StringIO()
deleted_lines: import cStringIO as StringIO buff = StringIO.StringIO()

commit_message:
Add Constraints support

Adding constraints support to clients is slightly more complex than
services as the clients themselves are listed in upper-constraints.txt
which leads to errors that you can't install a specific version and a
constrained version.

This change adds constraints support by also adding a helper script to
edit the constraints to remove ceilometer.

Change-Id: I8bdf866f0304649720adbfde1753e22ca248d432
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/97/412097/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: minversion = 1.8install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages}# NOTE(jaegerandi): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Set grub timeout default

Set the grub timeout to 5 seconds by default, and add notes on how to
update this.  This will stop infra having to carry an element that
goes and rewrites the grub configuration.

Change-Id: I556b3f48eff1b67ee8c4b9b64f749af95100fb99

It's also possible to enforce the use of Extlinux by exporting a ``DIB_EXTLINUX`` variable to the environment. Arguments ========= * ``DIB_GRUB_TIMEOUT`` sets the ``grub`` menu timeout. It defaults to 0 (no timeout) for fast boot times.
deleted_lines: Installs grub[2] on boot partition on the system. In case GRUB2 is not available in the system, a fallback to Extlinux will happen. It's also possible to enforce the use of Extlinux by exporting a DIB_EXTLINUX variable to the environment.

commit_message:
Fix LOG marker to follow the Python 3 guideline

"log.warn" which is functionally identical to "log.warning",
is deprecated in Python 3 .
we'd better use "log.warning" instead.

Change-Id: I7e09294d4b69eea5756bdc0af5facfdbe94ab364

subject: Switch wsgi test to use rspec-puppet-facts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-20 17:08:05.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/nova_wsgi_apache_spec.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/7b897406aa8beb42286112385eb40990cc0561ac', 'message': 'Switch wsgi test to use rspec-puppet-facts

The apache module expects the operatingsystem fact to be set and because
the wsgi tests were not using rspec-puppet-facts the missing fact is
causing failures. This change switches the wsgi test to leverage
rspec-puppet-facts to ensure all the basic facts are being provided to
resolve the unit test failures.

commit_message:
Switch wsgi test to use rspec-puppet-facts

The apache module expects the operatingsystem fact to be set and because
the wsgi tests were not using rspec-puppet-facts the missing fact is
causing failures. This change switches the wsgi test to leverage
rspec-puppet-facts to ensure all the basic facts are being provided to
resolve the unit test failures.

Change-Id: Ic5d9bd9939ad153d92af2480742506c92acda2c6
Closes-Bug: #1651522

added_lines: context 'with default parameters' do context 'when overriding parameters using different ports' do context 'when ::nova::api is missing in the composition layer' do on_supported_os({ :supported_os => OSDefaults.get_supported_os }).each do |os,facts| context "on #{os}" do let (:facts) do facts.merge!(OSDefaults.get_facts({ :fqdn => 'some.host.tld'})) end let (:platform_parameters) do case facts[:osfamily] when 'Debian' { :httpd_service_name => 'apache2', :httpd_ports_file => '/etc/apache2/ports.conf', :wsgi_script_path => '/usr/lib/cgi-bin/nova', :api_wsgi_script_source => '/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/wsgi/nova-api.py', } when 'RedHat' { :httpd_service_name => 'httpd', :httpd_ports_file => '/etc/httpd/conf/ports.conf', :wsgi_script_path => '/var/www/cgi-bin/nova', :api_wsgi_script_source => '/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nova/wsgi/nova-api.py', } end end it_behaves_like 'apache serving nova with mod_wsgi'

commit_message:
Fix bashate errors and warnings (lint)

Fix 1 warning and 1 error in bash syntax:

1) E043: Arithmetic compound has inconsistent return semantics.
   Fix the bash syntax to be compliant.

2) ERROR: Split export and assignments in 2 files. Ignore the files.
   Fix the bash syntax to be compliant.
   Note: this test has been introducted by
   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/400542/

Change-Id: I3c1134336033a8b5f2d56cd87fa190d9a354ecc0
(cherry picked from commit 9031dcf62016c5ca198a39109425b9f063e131fc)

commit_message:
Invalidate token cache after token delete

After deleting a token, the token cache needs to be invalidated.
This was only happenning for persistent tokens.

This patch also calls the token cache invalidation on the token provider
so that it happens regardless of the token provider being used or if the
token has actually been persisted.

Change-Id: I496531a30559f0cf021c4478404093a99f2fbe3d

commit_message:
Noop the updates and ha jobs

Because these two jobs are always taking the full ~2:45 right now,
they're causing a huge queue in zuul, which is making it difficult
to even test patches intended to fix the jobs.  I propose we noop
them globally, and then our test patches can re-enable them as
needed.  This should keep the queue small and allow us to get
results quickly on test patches.

Note that I'm nooping them to failure to make it clear that they
still aren't working.

Change-Id: I02907f1e2c7bb82a98e7fa9f501dad751d861e6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/24/411424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo '*** The updates job is broken right now. Failing fast to save ci time. ***' exit 1 echo '*** The ha job is broken right now. Failing fast to save ci time. ***' exit 1

subject: Make tempurl functional tests clean up account keys
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-25 12:59:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/9d02a9d4c313af70a1c9a7ca1f77bab462bfac65', 'message': 'Make tempurl functional tests clean up account keys

Addresses a TODO in test/functional/test_account.py where
an account metadata test was having to clean up tempurl keys
in the account metadata that were left by another test in
a different module.

This patch:

* makes the tempurl tests clean up their keys from account
  metadata.

* makes the test_account.py:TestAccount class remove any
  pre-existing metadata before attempting any tests and
  replacing that metadata when all the tests in that class
  have completed. This is more robust than the existing code
  which only removes any tempurl keys that might be in the
  account - now you could have x-account-meta-foo = bar in
  the test account and test_account.py will still pass.

Change-Id: I874a9e23dfcdd1caa934945b46089f11b9f6de65

Addresses a TODO in test/functional/test_account.py where
an account metadata test was having to clean up tempurl keys
in the account metadata that were left by another test in
a different module. This cleanup is necessary because tests
in test_account.py fail if there is any pre-existing
account metadata.

This patch:

* makes the tempurl tests clean up their keys from account
  metadata.

* makes the test_account.py:TestAccount class remove any
  pre-existing metadata before attempting any tests and
  replacing that metadata when all the tests in that class
  have completed. This is more robust than the existing code
  which only removes any tempurl keys that might be in the
  account - now you could have x-account-meta-foo = bar in
  the test account and test_account.py will still pass.

* consolidates some common setup code currently repeated for

commit_message:
Make tempurl functional tests clean up account keys

Addresses a TODO in test/functional/test_account.py where
an account metadata test was having to clean up tempurl keys
in the account metadata that were left by another test in
a different module. This cleanup is necessary because tests
in test_account.py fail if there is any pre-existing
account metadata.

This patch:

* makes the tempurl tests clean up their keys from account
  metadata.

* makes the test_account.py:TestAccount class remove any
  pre-existing metadata before attempting any tests and
  replacing that metadata when all the tests in that class
  have completed. This is more robust than the existing code
  which only removes any tempurl keys that might be in the
  account - now you could have x-account-meta-foo = bar in
  the test account and test_account.py will still pass.

* consolidates some common setup code currently repeated for
  many of the functional test classes into into a BaseEnv class.

Change-Id: I874a9e23dfcdd1caa934945b46089f11b9f6de65

commit_message:
Allow provision/local to run without sudo

In commit 379eb1b81aa900773edf85c668af2773016bea1e we added the
ability to create directories with a different owner than the user
running ansible. This had the unwanted side effect of forcing that
user to have sudo permissions. This breaks our jobs running from
an unprivledged jenkins.

Instead, we should check for sudo and only provide the extra
arguments for directory creation if it is available. Otherwise,
we use the previous simple directory create.

Change-Id: Iae38d7e460e168baa0078d782c08032b7f1520c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/20/413220/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check for sudo privileges so we can use become if available command: id register: sudo_check become: true failed_when: false - name: Ensure local working dir exists (with sudo) when: "sudo_check.rc==0" - name: Ensure local working dir exists (without sudo) file: path: "{{ local_working_dir }}" state: directory when: "sudo_check.rc!=0"

subject: Storlets to become official - Proposed governance change
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-10 19:02:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/2db084d27c171ee88d38c4c760ad5aa1479a54a3', 'message': 'Storlets to become official - Proposed governance change

The storlets project is in active development for over a year now
mostly by NTT and IBM. The built from source docs are currently
here: http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

The project has been presented in the Paris and Tokyo
summits, and we are looking forward to present it in Barcelona
hopefully tracking more interest and increasing the team.

Change-Id: Icf9dd346c731dd7378ba9015bd3cbc31e4246a6a
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-08-12 20:03:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/46dc05e73a4deb515a2529084564139a22eff4b9', 'message': 'Storlets to become official - Proposed governance change

The project offers the ability to run user defined functions
within Openstack Swift nodes. For more info please refer to
the docs (built from source) here:
http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

The project combines a Swift middleware together with Docker
to execute the user defined Java programs inside a container,
which in turn runs on Swift nodes. In addition the repository
has several Java written storlets used for functional tests
(as well as examples).

Open Source:
License: Apache 2.0 license.
Libraries: On top of what swift requires, storlets make use
of docker, JRE-8 plus standard Java libs. Non standard java
libs that we use are:
- simple-json (Apache 2.0 lic)
- logback-classic, logback-core (EPL v1.0 and the LGPL 2.1)
- slf4j-api (MIT lic)

Open Community:
We are currently 4 active contributors, 1 from IBM, 2 from NTT
and this commit author (independent developer) we hold weekly
meetings: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Storlets

Open Development:
The project is integrated with the Openstack CI, and was created
according to Openstack "Project Creator's Guide".
We work closely with the Swift team, and one of our cores is also a
core in Swift. Yours truly was elected to be the first PTL by the team.
Our current and near term goals are documented in our wiki.

Open Design:
So far our design meetings were alongside those of Swift. Otherwise,
most of the work is done through Gerrit and our IRC channel. In addition
we have the [storlets] prefix within the openstack-dev ML.

Interoperability:
Our user facing APIs are actually an extension of Swift’s API
(http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/overview_api.html)
To the best of my understanding, storlets being a Swift extension
do not pose any authentication restriction or integration issues.

Testing interface:
We have regular unit/functional/python style tests running with every
review request. We generate a source tar ball of the python code as
part of the deployment scripts, and generate documentation.

The project has been presented in the Paris and Tokyo
summits, and we are looking forward to present it in Barcelona
hopefully tracking more interest and increasing the team.

Change-Id: Icf9dd346c731dd7378ba9015bd3cbc31e4246a6a

according to Openstack "Project Creator's Guide".

core in Swift. Yours truly was elected to be the first PTL by the team.

Open Design:

most of the work is done through Gerrit and our IRC channel. In addition
we have the [storlets] prefix within the openstack-dev ML.

Interoperability:
Our user facing APIs are actually an extension of Swift’s API
(http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/overview_api.html)
To the best of my understanding, storlets being a Swift extension
do not pose any authentication restriction or integration issues.

Testing interface:
We have regular unit/functional/python style tests running with every
review request. We generate a source tar ball of the python code as
part of the deployment scripts, and generate documentation.

The project has been presented in the Paris and Tokyo
summits, and we are looking forward to present it in Barcelona
hopefully tracking more interest and increasing the team.

Reasoning about languages used:
We use Python, Java and C.
Java is used as the programming language for storlets. That is, the user defined
code running inside the Docker container on the storage node is Java. The initial
thought was that application developers are Java 'speakers', and indeed the first
POC we did with storlets writers was around a media use case and they were all Java.
To support Java written storlets we need some 'agent' code that can load and execute
the user supplied jar.
Similar to OpenStack SDK we would like to support a set of bindings and we are
currently working on a Python 'binding'.

We use C  for passing fds between Swift and the Dockered storlet, and only for that
purpose. Unfortunately, neither python 2.7 nor Java have support of passing fds
between processes (over UDS). This feature is crucial for us as we want to keep the
Docker container isolated as much as possible. Apparently, python 3.x does have
such support, but seems that on the Java side we will still need the C code.

Python is used for the Swift middleware. The middleware intercepts Swift requests
that wish to invoke a storlet on some data and routes the data to/from the storlet.

JRE Dependency:
We are now using Oracle's. I am not aware of any specific dependency on Oracle
other then the fact OpenJDK was mentioned as problematic. We will look into this

Is this being implemented anywhere else:
There have been https://zerovm.readthedocs.io/zerocloud/overview.html
However, after being aquired by Rackspace they have 'disappeared'.
We have tried to design storlets so that different runtime sandboxes
are pluggable with Docker containers being our first implementation
of a runtime sandbox. Having said that, as long as we have only one
implementation, this design has not been put to the test.

There is also what has been a proprietary solution and now opensourced
https://www.joyent.com/manta

Change-Id: Icf9dd346c731dd7378ba9015bd3cbc31e4246a6a
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-12-15 09:21:20.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/f50199d8d01f315c0ba381ed298541c6dde05f51', 'message': 'Storlets to become official - Proposed governance change

[1] Has a summary as well detailed desciption of all that
the team has done following the comments given in August.

The below is the original commit message describing the project
(with some necessary updates).

The project offers the ability to run user defined functions
within Openstack Swift nodes. For more info please refer to
the docs (built from source) here:
http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

The project combines a Swift middleware together with Docker
to execute the user defined Java/Python programs inside a container,
which in turn runs on Swift nodes. In addition the repository
has several sample storlets used for functional tests
(as well as examples).

Open Source:
License: Apache 2.0 license.
Libraries: On top of what swift requires, storlets make use
of docker, OpenJDK JRE-8 plus standard Java libs. Non standard java
libs that we use are:
- simple-json (Apache 2.0 lic)
- logback-classic, logback-core (EPL v1.0 and the LGPL 2.1)
- slf4j-api (MIT lic)

Open Community:
We are currently 5 active contributors, 1 from IBM, 3 from NTT
and this commit author (independent developer) we hold weekly
meetings in #openstack-meetings, with agenda posted in [2]

Open Development:
The project is integrated with the Openstack CI, and was created
according to Openstack "Project Creator's Guide".
We work closely with the Swift team, and one of our cores is also a
core in Swift. Yours truly was elected to be the first PTL by the team.
Our current and near term goals are documented in our wiki.

Open Design:
So far our design meetings were alongside those of Swift. Otherwise,
most of the work is done through Gerrit and our IRC channel. In addition
we have the [storlets] prefix within the openstack-dev ML.

Interoperability:
Our user facing APIs are actually an extension of Swift’s API
(http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/overview_api.html)
To the best of my understanding, storlets being a Swift extension
do not pose any authentication restriction or integration issues.

Testing interface:
We have regular unit/functional/python style tests running with every
review request. We generate a source tar ball of the python code as
part of the deployment scripts, and generate documentation.

The project has been presented in the Paris, Tokyo and Barcelona
summits.

Reasoning about languages used:
We use Python, Java and C.
Java and Python are used as the programming language for storlets.
That is, the user defined code running inside the Docker container on the storage
node can be Java or Python. Java is widly used in the Big-Data analytics world as
well as in the media world (as demonstrated in our Paris and Barcelona talks).
Similar to OpenStack SDK we would like to support a set of bindings and we are
currently working on a Python 'binding'.

We use C  for passing fds between Swift and the Dockered storlet, and only for that
purpose. Unfortunately, neither python 2.7 nor Java have support of passing fds
between processes (over UDS). This feature is crucial for us as we want to keep the
Docker container isolated as much as possible. Apparently, python 3.x does have
such support, but seems that on the Java side we will still need the C code.

Python is used for the Swift middleware. The middleware intercepts Swift requests
that wish to invoke a storlet on some data and routes the data to/from the storlet.

JRE Dependency:
We are now using OpenJDK.

Is this being implemented anywhere else:
There have been https://zerovm.readthedocs.io/zerocloud/overview.html
However, after being aquired by Rackspace they have 'disappeared'.
We have tried to design storlets so that different runtime sandboxes
are pluggable with Docker containers being our first implementation
of a runtime sandbox. Having said that, as long as we have only one
implementation, this design has not been put to the test.

There is also what has been a proprietary solution and now opensourced
https://www.joyent.com/manta
Joyent was aquired by Samsung this year.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/storlets-big-tent
[2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Storlets

Change-Id: Icf9dd346c731dd7378ba9015bd3cbc31e4246a6a
'}]
commit_message:
Storlets to become official - Proposed governance change

[1] Has a summary as well detailed desciption of all that
the team has done following the comments given in August.

The below is the original commit message describing the project
(with some necessary updates).

The project offers the ability to run user defined functions
within Openstack Swift nodes. For more info please refer to
the docs (built from source) here:
http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

The project combines a Swift middleware together with Docker
to execute the user defined Java/Python programs inside a container,
which in turn runs on Swift nodes. In addition the repository
has several sample storlets used for functional tests
(as well as examples).

Open Source:
License: Apache 2.0 license.
Libraries: On top of what swift requires, storlets make use
of docker, OpenJDK JRE-8 plus standard Java libs. Non standard java
libs that we use are:
- simple-json (Apache 2.0 lic)
- logback-classic, logback-core (EPL v1.0 and the LGPL 2.1)
- slf4j-api (MIT lic)

Open Community:
We are currently 5 active contributors, 1 from IBM, 3 from NTT
and this commit author (independent developer) we hold weekly
meetings in #openstack-meetings, with agenda posted in [2]

Open Development:
The project is integrated with the Openstack CI, and was created
according to Openstack "Project Creator's Guide".
We work closely with the Swift team, and one of our cores is also a
core in Swift. Yours truly was elected to be the first PTL by the team.
Our current and near term goals are documented in our wiki.

Open Design:
So far our design meetings were alongside those of Swift. Otherwise,
most of the work is done through Gerrit and our IRC channel. In addition
we have the [storlets] prefix within the openstack-dev ML.

Interoperability:
Our user facing APIs are actually an extension of Swift’s API
(http://storlets.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/overview_api.html)
To the best of my understanding, storlets being a Swift extension
do not pose any authentication restriction or integration issues.

Testing interface:
We have regular unit/functional/python style tests running with every
review request. We generate a source tar ball of the python code as
part of the deployment scripts, and generate documentation.

The project has been presented in the Paris, Tokyo and Barcelona
summits.

Reasoning about languages used:
We use Python, Java and C.
Java and Python are used as the programming language for storlets.
That is, the user defined code running inside the Docker container on the storage
node can be Java or Python. Java is widly used in the Big-Data analytics world as
well as in the media world (as demonstrated in our Paris and Barcelona talks).
Similar to OpenStack SDK we would like to support a set of bindings and we are
currently working on a Python 'binding'.

We use C  for passing fds between Swift and the Dockered storlet, and only for that
purpose. Unfortunately, neither python 2.7 nor Java have support of passing fds
between processes (over UDS). This feature is crucial for us as we want to keep the
Docker container isolated as much as possible. Apparently, python 3.x does have
such support, but seems that on the Java side we will still need the C code.

Python is used for the Swift middleware. The middleware intercepts Swift requests
that wish to invoke a storlet on some data and routes the data to/from the storlet.

JRE Dependency:
We are now using OpenJDK.

Is this being implemented anywhere else:
There have been https://zerovm.readthedocs.io/zerocloud/overview.html
However, after being aquired by Rackspace they have 'disappeared'.
We have tried to design storlets so that different runtime sandboxes
are pluggable with Docker containers being our first implementation
of a runtime sandbox. Having said that, as long as we have only one
implementation, this design has not been put to the test.

There is also what has been a proprietary solution and now opensourced
https://www.joyent.com/manta
Joyent was aquired by Samsung this year.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/storlets-big-tent
[2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Storlets

Change-Id: Icf9dd346c731dd7378ba9015bd3cbc31e4246a6a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/93/353693/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: storlets: ptl: name: Eran Rom irc: eranrom email: eran@itsonlyme.name irc-channel: openstack-storlets mission: > To enable a user friendly, cost effective scalable and secure way for executing storage centric user defined functions near the data within Openstack Swift url: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Storlets tags: - team:diverse-affiliation deliverables: storlets: repos: - openstack/storlets tags: - release:independent - type: service-extension

commit_message:
Amend reference/PTI with supported distros

It became clear that Ubuntu and CentOS are the 2 most-popular platforms
when deploying OpenStack.

https://www.openstack.org/assets/survey/April-2016-User-Survey-Report.pdf

We recently saw some cases where some projects implemented some features
that could not work on these platforms.

Example: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/401985/
- A feature in Neutron couldn't work with latest CentOS.
- Neutron and more projects are not gating on CentOS platform, only
  Ubuntu.

The goal of this change is to document that we would like to support
Ubuntu and CentOS in our testing and also collaborate with distros when
a dependency is not fresh enough to bring new features in OpenStack.

Change-Id: I8d63a883b29eda2757656008be3c6af83b8f9e88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/40/402940/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The following operating systems are the most popular when deploying OpenStack: - Ubuntu (`current LTS`_) - CentOS (`current stable`_) Each project should run functional tests on these platforms so we make sure OpenStack works with distros used in production. .. NOTE(emilien) I don't think it should resides in this reference but I also would like to express: Projects should be able to be tested on these platforms by taking in account that versions of dependencies are packaged in these distros might not be sufficient. When it happens, collaboration should be engaged between distros and OpenStack developpers to update a dependency that would be required to implement new features in OpenStack. Feel free to comment here, and give insights on whether or not it's important to document it, and where. .. _current LTS: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Releases .. _curent stable: https://www.centos.org/download/

commit_message:
move non_root_user variable to extras-common

This variable is defined in qs/roles/provision and
some invocations of qs skip provision.  This variable
needs to be defined in a role that is not skipped.

Change-Id: Ie153c23da785e34c3b7492b20c69ba5132c7baec

commit_message:
Set the default event pipeline publisher

Since we have aodh enabled for alarms, we should set the
notifier to the default queue alarm.all.

Closes-bug: #1590473

Change-Id: Ibcb5076424ac2ddcd18ff717d82da1aec4c035cb

commit_message:
mysql: remove 'test' default database

When MySQL start for the first time, it creates a 'test' database. It's
useless to keep it, so let's remove it.

Note: we already remove it on the overcloud.
Change-Id: Iad6646693f9bf65bdb6a530d807fb83de8cdb7cc

commit_message:
Don't require mistralclient for password gen

Update the generate_overcloud_passwords function so
that it no longer explicitly requires mistralclient.
This is useful to the python-tripleoclient undercloud
installer which would like to re-use this function
and does not currently run mistral.

This patch also renames the function so that it is more
clear these passwords would get used by both the
undercloud and overcloud installers.

Change-Id: I87fe5b3c2237d2f5a9b3b4b97216b87c548cf78d

The 3 node multinode job tests with a primary node and 2 subnodes. The
primary node is used for the undercloud. The 2 subnodes are used for the
overcloud. The overcloud services are split between pacemaker managed
services and non pacemaker managed services on the 2 subnodes. The first
subnode has the minimal set of services for an all-in-one overcloud with
the exception of any pacemaker service (galera, rabbitmq, etc) which are
on the second subnode.

This job adds coverage of non-default composable roles since a custom
roles data yaml file has to be used to split up the services in this
manner across the 2 subnodes.

commit_message:
Add 3 node multinode job

The 3 node multinode job tests with a primary node and 2 subnodes. The
primary node is used for the undercloud. The 2 subnodes are used for the
overcloud. The overcloud services are split between pacemaker managed
services and non pacemaker managed services on the 2 subnodes. The first
subnode has the minimal set of services for an all-in-one overcloud with
the exception of any pacemaker service (galera, rabbitmq, etc) which are
on the second subnode.

This job adds coverage of non-default composable roles since a custom
roles data yaml file has to be used to split up the services in this
manner across the 2 subnodes.

Depends-On: I8fc39e6d18cd70ff881e2a284234b26261018d67
Change-Id: I0cee6ff8b5c3002d45a6e66e4657baffa99ac5a6

Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. This mapping overrides those in ServiceNetMapDefaults. type: json DefaultPasswords: default: {} type: json EndpointMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json Debug: type: string default: '' resources: outputs: role_data: description: Role data for the Keystone role. value: service_name: core config_settings: tripleo.core.firewall_rules: '999 core': proto: 'udp' dport: - 4789

commit_message:
Add configurable mtu to --mulitnode-setup

Testing multinode environments on different clouds has shown that mtu on
the configured openvswitch interfaces may need to be lower than the
hardcoded value used in ovs_vxlan_bridge function from devstack-gate,
which is 1450.

This patch adds a $MTU variable which can be set to reconfigure the mtu
on the created interfaces after ovs_vxlan_bridge has been run.

This patch also makes a small change to make $BASE overrideable (which
is a variable used by devstack-gate).

Change-Id: I89147bb732664ba143446baa1c69232370db98bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/62/385162/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MTU=${MTU:-"1450"}BASE=${BASE:-$TRIPLEO_ROOT} export BASE export TRIPLEO_ROOT sudo ip link set dev $PUB_BRIDGE_NAME mtu $MTU ssh $SSH_OPTIONS -t -i /etc/nodepool/id_rsa $ip \ sudo ip link set dev $PUB_BRIDGE_NAME mtu $MTU
deleted_lines: export BASE=${BASE:-"/opt/stack"}

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: I6117fc818c44ac31ae656c18ed7fe5434fa73b77
Related-Bug: #1628580
Closes-Bug: #1645474
(cherry picked from commit b7d3c18b2a094be683138a3743480f83f48c5add)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/74/407074/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try_sleep => 5, tries => 10,

commit_message:
Make the neutron_l3_agent provider compatible with Puppet 4

We need to change the way it requires puppet/provider/neutron, or
it will fail with:

"Error: Could not autoload
puppet/provider/neutron_l3_agent_config/ini_setting: cannot load
such file -- puppet/provider/neutron"

Change-Id: Ic6f494b4c614d604f5691c95b2f67705a91bf682
(cherry picked from commit 3a456e1de17d2cd7d5b88408898fb1e87b48d432)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/42/411642/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require File.join(File.dirname(__FILE__), '..','..','..', 'puppet/provider/neutron')
deleted_lines: require 'puppet/provider/neutron'

commit_message:
Add --setup-nodepool-files option

This option will setup the expected nodepool files that are not present
when using multinode deployments on systems not spawned by nodepool. We
don't have to use this option in tripleo-ci since nodepool spawned
instances are in use. However, this is a useful helper option when doing
local deployments.

Change-Id: I8fa2f21fb693307440f661606e3193e1aa942c0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/60/385160/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo " --setup-nodepool-files -- Setup nodepool files on subnodes." -l,help,repo-setup,delorean-setup,delorean-build,multinode-setup,bootstrap-subnodes,undercloud,overcloud-images,register-nodes,introspect-nodes,overcloud-deploy,overcloud-update,overcloud-delete,use-containers,overcloud-pingtest,undercloud-upgrade,skip-pingtest-cleanup,all,enable-check,run-tempest,setup-nodepool-files \SETUP_NODEPOOL_FILES=${SETUP_NODEPOOL_FILES:-""} PRIMARY_NODE_IP=${PRIMARY_NODE_IP:-""} SUB_NODE_IPS=${SUB_NODE_IPS:-""} NODEPOOL_REGION=${NODEPOOL_REGION:-"nodepool_region"} NODEPOOL_CLOUD=${NODEPOOL_CLOUD:-"nodepool_cloud"} --setup-nodepool-files) SETUP_NODEPOOL_FILES="1"; shift 1;; mkdir -p $TRIPLEO_ROOTfunction setup_nodepool_files { log "Setup nodepool files" clone openstack-dev/devstack clone openstack-infra/devstack-gate clone openstack-infra/tripleo-ci if [ ! -d $BASE/new ]; then ln -s $TRIPLEO_ROOT $BASE/new fi sudo mkdir -p /etc/nodepool sudo chown -R $(whoami): /etc/nodepool if [ ! -f /etc/nodepool/id_rsa ]; then ssh-keygen -N "" -t rsa -f /etc/nodepool/id_rsa fi if [ -z $PRIMARY_NODE_IP ]; then echo '$PRIMARY_NODE_IP must be defined. Exiting.' exit 1 fi echo $PRIMARY_NODE_IP > /etc/nodepool/node echo $PRIMARY_NODE_IP > /etc/nodepool/primary_node echo $PRIMARY_NODE_IP > /etc/nodepool/primary_node_private echo -n > /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes echo -n > /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes_private for sub_node_ip in $SUB_NODE_IPS; do echo $sub_node_ip >> /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes echo $sub_node_ip >> /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes_private ssh $SSH_OPTIONS -tt $sub_node_ip sudo mkdir -p $TRIPLEO_ROOT ssh $SSH_OPTIONS -tt $sub_node_ip sudo chown -R $(whoami): $TRIPLEO_ROOT rsync -e "ssh $SSH_OPTIONS" -avhP $TRIPLEO_ROOT $sub_node_ip:$TRIPLEO_ROOT/.. rsync -e "ssh $SSH_OPTIONS" -avhP /etc/nodepool $sub_node_ip: ssh $SSH_OPTIONS -tt $sub_node_ip sudo cp -r nodepool /etc ssh $SSH_OPTIONS $sub_node_ip \ "/bin/bash -c 'cat /etc/nodepool/id_rsa.pub >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys'" done echo "NODEPOOL_REGION=$NODEPOOL_REGION" > /etc/nodepool/provider echo "NODEPOOL_CLOUD=$NODEPOOL_CLOUD" >> /etc/nodepool/provider log "Setup nodepool files - DONE" } if [ "$SETUP_NODEPOOL_FILES" = 1 ]; then setup_nodepool_files fi

commit_message:
Use OS::Heat::DeployedServer

The new DeployedServer resource in Heat will provide a native resource
for Server resources that are not orchestrated via Nova. This will allow
associating SoftwareDeployment's with servers that have not been
launched with Nova with Heat directly.

With the new resource, all of the SoftwareConfigTransport methods are
available, including POLL_TEMP_URL. This patch also updates the
get-occ-config.sh script to configure the requests collector in
os-collect-config.conf on the deployed servers.

Change-Id: I4b80421088acca709fe3f92741c5c052be483131
Partially-implements: blueprint split-stack-software-configuration
Depends-On: I07b9a053ecd3ef4411b602bbc6ef985224834cf8

commit_message:
Try to create workdir without sudo if sudo fails

If owner of the directory is user running ansible, this
will work without sudo, so we should check it for cases
where user is the same and not sudo is available.

Change-Id: I13f8a1416d186abc8f9bbe12d06dd5b6f70ad30a

Mark OpenShift templates as deprecated

an ongoing basis and are now superseded.

commit_message:
Move bandit to pep8

The bandit gate is passing, let's make it voting.

Since bandit is a security linter, add it to the linter target - called
pep8 - and run it there. This will save the CI systems spawning an extra
test machine for this.

Needed-By: I90e5401ee8e46a2a153adb62d0f99a8a88a686b8
Change-Id: I75eeefa2441466da60b9b206769a2e64e9c1e7a9

commit_message:
Added retries for db_sync

If db sync fails, it is never retried leading to errors. So, this
patch adds retries for db_sync to avoid sync fails.

Change-Id: I6a19e10ec305f54232293fd9807217291bf50875
Related-Bug: #1628580
Closes-Bug: #1645474
(cherry picked from commit bac067fff5a8194a7093e29a1845450a4e329183)

Remove the useless parameter

commit_message:
Add release names for P and Q to versionutils

This will allow the real release names (Pike and Queens [1]) to appear
in deprecation messages, etc.

[1]: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-August/101891.html

Change-Id: Ibc5e03f8cd502c262f44c27671c9bede11452230
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/95/358695/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: remove_in='Pike') @mock.patch('oslo_log.versionutils.report_deprecated_feature') def test_deprecated_for_removal_in_unnamed_release(self, mock_reporter): @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.PIKE, remove_in=+2) class OutdatedClass(object): pass obj = OutdatedClass() self.assertIsInstance(obj, OutdatedClass) self.assert_deprecated(mock_reporter, what='OutdatedClass()', as_of='Pike', remove_in='R')
deleted_lines: remove_in='P')

commit_message:
Auto-enable heat cinder backup functionality

This patch automatically enables heat's cinder backup functionality
if cinder's backup service is enabled.

This patch depends on a patch applied to the `os_heat` role (see
Depends-on below).

Closes-Bug: 1650035
Depends-on: I3875cc34ec92ba588d995a6d9c0341977a408ad7
Change-Id: I64db5d2bce6ac74d4d0b0f9314f3b305ac730bd0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/77/413177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | If the cinder backup service is enabled with ``cinder_service_backup_program_enabled: True``, then heat will be configured to use the cinder backup service. The ``heat_cinder_backups_enabled`` variable will automatically be set to ``True``.

commit_message:
Adding name to health monitor and member

1) Refactor to have a new name mixin to unify names in Octavia
2) Add name to the two tables and have migration scripts

Change-Id: Ic60b9c8c28f7a99de2d36c98a28afac830b24947
Closes-Bug:#1635731
Closes-Bug:#1635740
